So following your argument, there is really no reason whatsoever to standar=
dise the link header with custom relationships, as if you don't understand =
the relationship you can do nothing with the link. The arc is not pointing =
to a resource anymore anyway so you've given up all value. 

In my pedantic=
 view, breaking expectations won't work and shoehorning is an issue. 

Than=
ks god Firefox doesn't start understanding uri templates in href attributes=
, this would lead to fragmentation, and even non pedantic people would agre=
e that it's not a good idea. 

--
Sebastien Lambla


On 27 Jan 2012, at 17:=
16, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:

> On Fri, Jan 27, 2012 at=
 4:48 PM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
>> You introduce coup=
ling to your definition to understand a link.
> 
> Yes, this is what link r=
elations are for.
> 
>> An atom link expects an identifier, not an identifi=
er template. Same goes
>> with rfc5988.
>> 
>> You establish with those kno=
wn links a relationship between two resources,
>> the current one and the r=
esource /blah/{introyourtemplatehere}
>> 
>> Rewriting what identifiers mea=
n (here, from identification to identification
>> builder) is shoehorning c=
oncepts into one that should not be mucked about
>> with (the identifier of=
 a resource).
> 
> .. so what are the actual problems you are foreseeing?
>=
 
> Afaict, the worst that will happen is clients are unaware of the
> temp=
lated nature of the link (implied by the rel) will dereference it
> as if i=
t were a plain URI. Is that really a big deal?
> 
> 'Shoehorning' is one (a=
rguably pedantic) way of looking at it.. I just
> look it as sensible re-us=
e of existing mechanisms e.g. you can now
> have templated/query links in t=
he Link header for free, same with your
> custom rels in Atom.
> 
> Cheers,=

> Mike
